titleStmt.title: The agreeable surprise: A comic opera. In two acts. By Mr. O'Keefe. The music composed by Dr. Arnold.
titleStmt.author: O'Keeffe, John, 1747-1833.

fileDesc.extent: 36 600dpi bitonal TIFF page images and SGML/XML encoded text

The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: The agreeable surprise: A comic opera. In two acts. By Mr. O'Keefe. The music composed by Dr. Arnold.
titleStmt.author: O'Keeffe, John, 1747-1833.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE MUSIC COMPOSED BY DR. ARNOLD.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.p: Sir Felix Friendly and Compton diſcovered ſitting, John and Thomas waiting behind, country lads and laſſes at a diſtance, ſinging chorus as the curtain riſes.

sp.l: HERE we ſing, dance and play,
Nor perceive the blithe day
Is departing, when gliding ſo ſmoothly away.

sp.speaker: Compton.
sp.l: Let poets ſtill carol the beauties of Spring,
And love-lorn ſhepherds of ſummer may ſing;
'Tis Autumn beſtows full fruition of joy,
Rich treaſure, ſweet pleaſure that never can cloy.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.l: The yellow leaf falling, preſents the wiſe page,
That bids us lay up for our winter of age;
While labour ſubſiding, ſtill ſweetens repoſe,
And our wealth, roſy health, from induſtry flows.
Here we ſing, &c.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: There there, get you gone all to the lawn, and be as merry as good cheer, ſtrong beer, and the pipe and tabour can make you.

sp.speaker: Peaſants.
sp.p: Long life and happy days to our maſter ſir Felix!

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: O Compton! I'm ſo happy to-day! Isn't that your old ſervant Thomas?

sp.speaker: Compton.
sp.p: Ay, ſir Felix, now my only ſervant: fidelity roots the poor fellow in a barren ſoil.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Deſire Lingo to come here,
Here Thomas, drink my health,

We'll have none of our verdure wither
to day, for want of moiſture.

Ah, friend Compton, had you but continued partnerſhip with me to this day, well—Ay, ay, I ſtuck to Blackwell-hall, till I converted my wool into a golden fleece. You muſt, like a ſilly ſheep, go privateering, and ſo be fleeced by the French and Spaniards.

sp.speaker: Compton.
sp.p: Why, ſir Felix, no reflections on the part you have taken, I thought it more honourable to be ſhorn in facing the foe, than in ſafety to carry back a branded fleece, by flying from the enemies of my country.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Well ſaid, my old battering ram. You're a loyal ſubject, and ſhall never be without his Majeſty's picture, while I have a collection. A friend to the King ſhould never want his countenance. You're a true patriot too; and it's a pity, that a lover of his country ſhould ever be in want of the bleſſings ſhe produces. But come, give me the ſong that firſt ſet you agog on privateering.

sp.speaker: Compton.
sp.p: Sir Felix, I ſhan't repine at my private loſſes, ſo long as we can keep the dominion of the ſea, and preſerve the Trident put into our hands by our valiant forefathers.

lg.l: Thus, thus, my boys, our anchor's weigh'd,
Sound, found your ſhells, ye, Tritons ſound,
Let ev'ry heart with joy redound,
See Neptune quit his watry car,
To hail the free-born Britiſh tar,
A fail a-head, our decks we clear.
Our canvaſs crowd, the chace we near,
A broadſide pour'd through clouds of ſmoak,
Our captain roars, my hearts of oak,
Now draw, and board our prize.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Thank ye, thank ye, old partner I Od! I'm ſo happy to-day!

sp.speaker: Compton.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, Felix, may I beg to know the cauſe of this happineſs, and theſe extraordinary preparations?

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Why Compton, 'tis neceſſary you ſhould know this day is a triple feſtival, a little calendar, man, my birth day, harveſt home, and Laura's wedding.

sp.speaker: Compton.
sp.p: My daughter! To whom, ſir Felix?

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: To my ſon.

sp.speaker: Compton.
sp.p: Eugene! I'm ſurpriſed!

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: I love to ſurpriſe people with good news.— You know this was always my intention.

sp.speaker: Compton.
sp.p: And is this all certain?

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: True as that you have brought up my ſon as yours, and I your daughter as an orphan that I had adopted. You know they love each other, and in this union of hearts my grand point is anſwered. I am ſo happy my ſon, by thinking himſelf not worth a ſhilling, has eſcaped the foppery and ideas of diſſipation he might have imbibed from a knowledge of being heir to my fortune; and in your Laura I ſhall have a daughter-in-law poſſeſſed of ſenſe to diſtinguiſh 〈◊〉 it, though linked to poverty, and generoſity to reward it with her heart.

sp.speaker: Compton.
sp.p: Dear ſir Felix, this goodneſs to a child of mine, is a meaſure I—

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p:
You wicked man, would you oppoſe goodneſs?— Ha, ha, ha! this is pleaſant Laura loves Eugene, though ſhe thinks he's not worth a groat; and though he doats upon her, yet, awed by her fortune, the poor fool fighs at hnmble diſtance. Yes; and egad! there were folks ſighing for him too. Why, do you know, Compton, he has made a conqueſt of a rich cheeſemonger's widow in the Borough, who ſuppoſing him much poorer than herſelf, forced money upon him to lure his affections. Ha, ha, ha! this old mouldy
vidow will have him in ſpite of his teeth; and thinking him ſtill incapable of repaying her in coin, actually deſigns to hunt him with an attorney, and follow him here into the country, to force him into marriage. Ha, ha, ha! but where's Eugene now? becauſe the bridegroom's preſence is neceſſary at a wedding you know.

sp.speaker: Compton.
sp.p: I left him at home drawing.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: At ſtudy how to. get his bread by ſcratching upon copper, or daubing canvaſs. Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Compton.
sp.p: True, ſir Felix. From the idea he, has Fortune ſtill to court, he is diligent in improving every grace, and acquiring every accompliſhment that can render him worthy of her favour.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: And Laura in London, laying out a few hondreds I gave her this morning.

sp.speaker: Compton.
sp.p: Without an idea that I am her father, and even breathe but from your bounty. O ſir Felix! to ſo many obligations in the, ſcale, gratitude is a feather.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Then keep it to yourſelf, you feather-headed gooſe, Arn't we to be happy?— Compton, you took me into partnerſhip with you, when all my ſtock was a little honeſty; a poor capital, as the world goes! I have now the; means, you the inclination. And were you rich, and I poor, I know you'd act by me, as I mean to do by you. Here! Lingo, Lingo!

sp.speaker: Compton.
sp.p: I ſee you have brought home your new butler.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p:
Yes, ſir; but he's a curſt fellow, as ignorant as dirt, It ſeeems he has been a ſchoolmaſter here in the country, taught all the bumpkin fry what he calls Latin; and the damn'd dog ſo patches his own bad Engliſh with his bits of bad Latin, and jumbles the Gods, Goddeſſes, Heroes celeſtial and infernal together at ſuch a rate; I took him to oblige a fooliſh old friend of mine, who intended him for Saint Omers; ſo I
muſt keep him to draw good wine, and brew balderdaſh Latin.—Lingo!

sp.speaker: Compton.
sp.p: I ſee a carriage coming down the avenue.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Eh! it's Laura. Step you home for Eugene. D'ye hear, Compton? not a word till I break the matter myſelf. Edod! they'll be as happy!

sp.speaker: Compton.
sp.p: I am ſure they will be perfectly ſo.

lg.l: The virgin lily of the night,
But ſoon in coif of native white,
But freſh and blithe as Mar,
She riſes to perfume the morn,
The limpid ſtreams of noble ſource
O'er golden ſands they gently glide,

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: I'll puzzle 'em a little firſt though; their ſurpriſe and joy will be the greater.

div.stage: Enter Laura, Fringe and William, with band boxes, &c.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Eh! Laura! welcome home, my girl.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I thank you, ſir.—Here, Fringe, take theſe things into the houſe.

sp.speaker: Fringe.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Here, we are, eh!—very well.— Laid out all your caſh?—Well, well.—Did n't run in debt I hope?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: No ſir; your kindneſs amply ſupplied me.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: That's right. But come—your journal.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Now will he pretend to rail at my exravagance, altho' he delights in every wiſh of mine.
Firſt, ſir, I rattled up to my Milliner's in Bond ſtreet—Mrs. Bufont has a charming taſte.—There's a cap, ſir;—the very crown of elegance!

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: And coſt a crown in ſilver, I warrant now!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: A crown! dear ſir, it's cheap of three guineas.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Three guineas!—Bond-ſtreet!— They make mighty pretty caps in Cranbourn-alley.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: True. ſir. But if we don't yield a little to the faſhions of the times, we ſhall make a ruſty appearance to our poliſhed neighbours of the Continent.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Laura, I like a medium. I'll neither ruſt in particularity, nor will I be a weathercock to every puff of faſhion.

lg.l: In Jacky Bull, when bound for France,
Tho' taught to ride, to fence and dance,
With his tierce and carte, ſa! ſa!
And his cotillon ſo ſmart, ha! ha!
He charms each female heart, O la!
For cocks and dogs ſee ſquire at home
Return'd form Paris, Spa, or Rome,

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p:
For a trip or ſo, I ſhould have no objection to a ſnuff at the air of Fontainbleau; ſhould like to ſee the little chapel at Loretto, or the great tun of Heidelburg, or the Eſcurial, the bull feaſt, the goblins, tapeſtry, or, no offence
to his Holineſs's great toe, to pop my noſe into the Vatican. But after all, I ſhould be, unfaſhionable enough to prefer little England to all the gardens and fountains of France, and paiaces and converſationi of Italy.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I apprehend, ſir, I ſhould be ſomewhat of your opinion in that particular.

div.head: SONG.
div.l: The tuneful lark as ſoaring high,
With wonder views the vaulted ſky,
And gently dropping to its neſt,

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!—Poor Laura, I'll ſurpriſe you presently.—Lingo!—Where is this crazy butler of mine? Lingo!—O! here he comes at laſt. Now will he peſter me with his damn'd barbarous Latin.—Lingo!

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: I'm here, Domine Felix.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Domine! I'll Domine your blockhead againſt the wall, if you Domine me.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: I won't, Domine Felix.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Again!

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: I've done, Domine Felix.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Are your knives and glaſſes, and every thing ready for.ſupper?

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: All ready, Domine Felix.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: O damn your Domine!—Pray, Lingo, ſtir, and be clever;—a great deal to do; —And I beſeech you, let ine hear no more of your curſt Latin.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: My curſt Latin! a bleſſed ignorant; family this I have got. into!
Cudden, whither ſo faſt?

sp.speaker: Cudden.
sp.p: I am going upon the lawn to be merry, and to dance. with my ſweetheart Cowſlip the dairy-maid. We'll have ſuch game!—

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: Game! Cudden, you muſt know the Olympic games were propria quae maribus maſcula dicas.

sp.speaker: Cudden.
sp.p: I know nought of French, maſter Lingo. I loves to hear good Engliſh, becaufſ as why, I ſpeaks good Engliſh; and ſo good bye, meiſter butler.
O farmer Stump!

sp.speaker: Stump.
sp.p: I can't ſtay.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: You can't ſtay! O you Adonis of the wood!—Utſunt divorum, Mars, Bacchus, Apollo, virorum.

sp.speaker: Stump.
sp.p: I don't underſtand Greek.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: Ay, ay, all my Latin's Greek, to theſe people, you unhappy clowns, oh you Cyclops! they know nothing, nor won't be learned. Not a ſoul in the houſe will liſten to me but Cowſlip the dairy-maid; and ſhe's going to jig it upon the lawn with the dancing ſawns and ruſty bumpkins. And here ſhe comes.
sp.stage: Enter Cowſlip, with a bowl of cream.
sp.p: My ſweet Cowſlip, properly called Cowſlip. Nominativo hanc, huc. et hoe

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: I have, put the. hock into the ſyllabub, Mr. Lingo, and here it is.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: What a ſenſible ſoul it is!

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: Will you take it within, Mr. Lingo?

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p:
No child. I, prefer the air, Zephyrus, Aeolus, Boreas, and other gentle breezes will attend us here. I love the fragrant gales.
Cowſlip ſit down. You're a noun adjective, and muſt not ſtand by yourſelf. Let's have a toaſt.

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: I'll go bake one, ſir.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: No, I'll make one. Here's that the maſculine may never be neuter to the feminine gender.

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: Here's that—ay, here's the maſculine to. the feminine gender (drinks) O Lord! I left out the neuter.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: You. were, right. Recte, puella. I know theſe things, child, ſo did Ovid and Caeſar.

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: What, Caeſer, the great dog, ſir;

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: No, child! Judas Caeſar. Romulus and Remus were ſuckled by a wolf. They raviſhed the Sabine girls, and found Rome in Italy.

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: Ah! ſuch. fellows would find room any where.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: Jupiter was a fine god. He ſwam on a bull to Europe, He went into a flaſh of fire for Semele.

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, he'd go any lengths for his ale,

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: I. mean his amours.

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: O ay; he'd drink with Moors or Turks either.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: Drink! who?

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: Who! why Jew Peter, the old clothes man.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: O coelum in terra! for all my converſation, I find you know no more than the, parſun of the pariſh. Ah, Cowſlip, if you was a goddeſs! the goddeſſes knew men and things.

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: More ſhame for'em, Mr. Lingo, I ſay!

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: Jove loved an eagle, Mars a lion, Phoebus a cock, Venus a pigeon, Minerva loved an owl.

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: I.ſhould not have thought of your cock lions, your owls, and your pigeons, if I was a goddeſs. Give me a roaſt duck.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: If you was Flora or Ceres!

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: Serus! I am ſerus.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: O Cowſlip, the great old heroes perhaps you have never heard of, Homer, Moſes, Hecrules, or Wat Tyler!

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: No indeed, ſir, not I.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: Cowſlip, don't love the Clowns. That fellow, that Cudden, is a coloſſus of the road. He's a clown, a mere pheaſant; and yet, I ſuſpect this Faunus, this young Silenus is the deity, the great Pan of the dairy.

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: I could not ſet my cream, ſir, without a pan in the dairy.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: O Cowſlip, the fine gods but for a mortal exit Homo.

lg.l: What poſies, and roſes to noſes diſcloſes,
To the tip of your lip, as. they trip the bees dip,
Honey ſip like choice ſlip, and their Hybla forget.
When girls like you paſs us,
I'd quaff off a full can,
Or Jove the old bull cann,

div.head: SCENE II. A Chamber.
div.p: Where can Eugene be? at home, over his books and painting I ſuppoſe. He'd be here if he thought I was come back. Yes, he is all tenderneſs and attention; but his diffidence and provoking reſpect almoſt make me angry ſometimes. How a little abſence endears to us the object of our affection!

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: You have been in London, madam!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Juſt returned, Eugene. Why will you call me madam? you know! don't like it.

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: Impute my offence to the real cauſe, my reſpect to my divine Laura.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Send your reſpect back to its fource, the bounty of ſir Felix:

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: My love, you have my heart, my life: But when I reflect on the diſtance my fare has thrown me from you, it checks my preſumption. I endeavour to hide from ſelf-contempt, and would, if poſſible, ſhrink from my own opinion.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: What was I, Eugene? a poor, abandoned orphan; and but for the kind attention of ſir Felix, I ſhould be a wretched outcaſt, and experience the cold reception poverty muſt expect from a hard and ſordid world.

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: O my love, had we been born humble villagers; with my Laura I ſhould have been happy.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: And I too with, my Engene.

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.l: The bluſhing ſun ſhall never riſe
To ſteal the woodbine's pearly dew,
But thy dear name I'll breathe in ſighs,
And every thought ſhall be of you.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.l: Then penſive as a widow'd dove
I'll cheerleſs watch the lazy day.
And when kind dreams bring home my love,
I'll eager graſp the welcome ray.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Hence far with doubt and jealous fear,
With thee alone can joy return;
For thee I'll ſigh, for thee, my dear,
The lamp of love ſhall conſtant burn.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Compton, look there, a pair of turtles. Look, ſee there's looks of love.

sp.speaker: Compton.
sp.p: Unfeigned affection indeed ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Egad! I'll ſurpriſe them. I'll diſturb their tranquillity.

sp.speaker: Compton.
sp.p: Dear ſit—

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Be quier, man: Their joy will be the greater afterwards.—Ha! Eugene! my boy, we han't had a diſh of chat to-day.

sp.speaker: Eugere.
sp.p: The loſs was mine, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Compton, now for it.—Laura, do you knew that I am very happy to-day?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Dear ſir, you never call be happier than I ſincerely wiſh you.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: I thank you, child—Yes, yes— Ha, ha, ha! I delight in a wedding.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Sir!—

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: We are to have wedding under this; roof to-night, Eugene.

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: Indeed ſir?

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Yes; I am going to marry.

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: Who ſir?

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Laura.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Me, ſir!

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Yes; I am going to marry you to my ſon.

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: Son! Have you a ſon, ſir?

sp.speaker: Compton.
sp.p: He has, Eugene; a ſon worthy of ſuch a father?

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: And he is to be united to Laura!

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Yes, Eugene, he's a good lad. I'll aſſure you you'll like him exceedingly, Eugene. Egad! you'll never be out of his company. But he's at hand to bleſs my hopes, crown my wiſhes, and end my cares. You've no objection, Laura?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Gratitude, Sir, moſt ever make your will the guide of mine.—Till now I never felt the loſs of a parent. (Aſide)

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: Never till now did I regret the want of a fortune. (Aſide)

sp.speaker: Compton.
sp.p: My heart bleeds for them.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Nonſenſe! when happineſs comes unexpected, it brings a double bleſſing, and cheers like the ſun from behind a cloud.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.l: O how ſweetly pleaſure's taſted,
Uſher'd in by grief or pain;
Every joy ſome joy is waſted,
Give me ſunſhine after rain.

sp.speaker: Compton.
sp.l: A trial ſo ſevere diſcovers
True affection's real charms;
Hapleſs, happy, faithful lovers,
Soon you'll bleſs each other's arms.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.l: O exquiſite pleaſute! O joy beyond meaſure!
What ſay you, my Laura? what ſay you, my friend?
Then hey for a wedding, and hey for a bedding,
And hey for a babby at nine months end!

sp.speaker: Laura and Eugene.
sp.l: Celeſlial Patience! meek-ey'd maid,
Impart thy lenient pow'r.
With calm Content 'tis thou muſt aid,
And cheer and cheer the adverſe hour.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.l: We'll be merry, by jingo!
I've got ſome ſome old • elies
Of Bacchus;—What, Lingo!

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.l: You know my choice old ſack,
Go fetch a dozen bottles;
Brave Bacchus we'll attack,

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.l: And bi • o all our throttles.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.l: A feaſt's not worth a fig
Without a hearty jorum,

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.l: Hey populorum jig,
Hey jiggo populorum.
Hey populorum jig,
Hey jiggo populorum.

div.head: SCENE I. An Inn.
div.stage: Draws and diſcovers Mrs. Cheſhire and Chicane.

sp.speaker: Chicane.
sp.p: So, my glaſs of brandy and water is finiſhed, and by this time the horſes are putting to.

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: We'll be upon him. He has got my letter by this; and Sir Felix Friendly, who lives here below, has given me notice of Eugene's intentions to marry an orphan girl ſomewhere here in the country; but I think I'll forbid the banns. You've the writ ready, Mr. Chicane?

sp.speaker: Chicane.
sp.p: In my pocket. But, Mrs. Cheſhire, I truſt you'll let no tender qualm prevent the execution of it, In caſe the yonug man, this Eugene, ſhould refuſe to marry you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p:
Tender qualms! you're a good lawyer, I believe, Mr. Chicane, but you are little read in the heart of a woman. No, Sir; the more we love, the more we hate, when that love
is ſlighted. And am not I right, ſir? not a better filled cheeſe-ſhop in the Borough than mine. What would the fellow have? and pray, ſir, an't I a wife for any man?

sp.speaker: Chicane.
sp.p: Wife! ay, and a good wife too, Mrs. Cheſhire. And what's better, there's plenty of you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: Ah! that's what my poor dear huſband uſed to ſay. The good ſoul died of a ſurſeit at the London Tavern. Ay, mere curds and whey;—wouldn't do for a city feaſt. Delicate as Parmeſan, Mr. Chicane. Why, wife, ſays he, you're an honour to Tooley-ſtreet. A noble Cheſhire caſt in a Dutch mould. If he ſtill refuſes my hand and property—

sp.speaker: Chicane.
sp.p: To priſon he goes. Yes, I have got a bailiff that I think will have him, Yes, my bailiff's an agreeable fellow. Tom Touch has a moſt taking way with him. Yes, yes, he'll ſleep in the King's Bench to night.

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: Ay, as ſure as you have two ears upon your head, Mr. Chicane.

sp.speaker: Chicane.
sp.p: Then he's ſafe enough. (Aſide)

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: Yes, yes, to priſon he goes; and I think I am right, Sir.

sp.speaker: Chicane.
sp.p: Right! if not, Madam, I would not be concerned for you. I like to be on the right ſide; and in my laſt cauſe particularly, I lent an ear to justice.—She never repaired it though. (Aſide)

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: Come, Mr. Chicane, riſe—O! I hope the poor beaſts have fed. A tolerable pull to draw you and me in a gigg from London.

sp.speaker: Chicane.
sp.p: Only two hours and four minutes. You are an excellent driver, Mrs. Cheſhire.

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p:
A pretty work, ſir, in ſuch weather, driving my gigg after a fellow! I proteſt, ſir, though my dear huſband had a confirmed aſthma, and Was ſixty-eight when he died, I gave myſelf
more trouble about this Eugene, though the fellow is in found health, and is only twenty-four.

sp.speaker: Chicane.
sp.p: All from your good-nature, Mrs. Cheſhire.

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: Oh! if my poor dear huſband was alive—But he's better where he is.

lg.l: In choice of a huſband widows are nice,
I'd not have a man who'd grow old in a trice,
Not a hear or a monkey, a clown or a ſop,
But one that could buſtle and ſtir in my ſhop.
A log I'll avoid, when I'm choſing my lad,
And a ſtork that might gobble up all that I bad
Such ſuitors I've had, ſir. but off they might hop,
I want one that can buſtle and ſtir in my ſhop.
The lad in my eye is the man to my mind,
So haadſome, ſo young, ſo polite, and ſo kind,
With ſuch a good ſoul to the altar I'd pop,
He's the man that can buſtle and ſtir in my ſhop.

div.head: SCENE II. A Chamber.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! ſhe's come, Mrs. Cheſhire is come and brought an attorney upon him. How he will be ſurpriſed! A letter is her harbinger, and they'll be here in five minutes. Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Compton.
sp.p: I had not a notion 'twas you ſent for her, ſir Felix.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: I knew I'd ſurpriſe you. Ha, ha, ha!— We'll ſee how he'll fight it out. Egad! they'll ſurpriſe him. How finely he'll be hampered! an ideal rival on one ſide, and a real attorney on the other. Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Compton.
sp.p: And tantalized with forbidden fruitin the tempting affection of my Laura.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p:
Ay, but when I ſnatch him from the attorney, and the fat cheeſemonger, and bleſs
him with an affluent fortune and his dear Laura, how he'll be then ſurpriſed!

sp.speaker: Compton.
sp.p: Why certainly the winding up will be the beſt of the joke.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Joke! I live in a joke. A hearty laugh is my leaſe of happineſs; and on the farm of fun I'll be a tenant for life.

lg.l: While ſome do love full bowls to quaſſ,
Some like a dog and gun O!
But I a chearful, hearty laugh,
Give me a bit of fun O!
For I'll ſmile and jeſt, and do my beſt,
While life's hour-glaſs doth run O!
And while I can, tho' an old man,
I'll have a bit of fun O!
I lik'd a laſs both briſk and gay,
And after her did run O!
Then whiſper'd ſomething in her ear,
For I lov'd a bit of fun O!
So ripe tor ſport'and bliſs was ſhe,
I thought the buſineſs done O!
But when I fain would happy be,
Says ſhe, you're making fun O!
So with laugh, and joke, and mirth, and ſong,
At length her heart I won O!
And. then to church we went along,
And at night we had fome fun O!
Some like great bowls to quaff,
Some like a dog and gun;
I love a bit of fun.
I took her in my arms,
Says I, we'll have ſome fun
So ripe for ſport and play,
But when I ſain would kiſs,
With joke and laugh and play,
At length her heart I won;
To church we went that day,
At night we had ſome fun.

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: I wiſh I could get an opportunity of ſpeaking to Laura. I won't return to ſir Felix in ſuch a perturbed ſtate of mind. Company, converſation is—

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: Do ſir, come in and take a glaſs, do. Sir pray come in, and bibo a little with your father and Domine Felix. they are gone laughing into the parlour, and I have opened a bottle for 'em.

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: Well, Lingo, my reſpect to ſir Felix, and I ſhall do myſelf the honour of waiting on him at ſupper.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: No, ſir, 'tis I that am to wait on him at ſupper, becauſe I am the butler. Do, pray, ſir, come in to meo magiſter. You'll be heartily welcome to Domine Felix I'm ſure; and that the wine, is good, bona veritas I'm ſure; for I took two glaſſes juſt now at the. ſide-board.

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: Why then, pray go in and take another. Primo, ſecundo, tertio, Mr. Lingo.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: Primo, ſecundo, tertio! Mr. Eugene, you know ſomething, I know a little too. You, have ſtudied. Pray, ſir, was you an Oxonian, or a Cantab?

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: What an infernal fellow!

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: An infernal fellow! O then you wore a ſquare cap.—I'll poſe the infernal fellow of Oxford.—Pray, ſir, can you decline the amatum ſupine to a lady that's fine?

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: I find you are a great ſcholar Mr. Lingo.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p:
Scholar! I was a maſter of ſcholars. Scio ſcribendo, I can read. Legere, I can
write. Tacitorum Latinum, I can ſpeak Latin. But then, quid opus mihi uſumque ſciente? what need have I of ſo much knowledge? No one liſtens to me but Cowſlip the dairy-maid; and I admire her ſapience, for ſhe's as docile as a young elephant.

lg.l: As a cedar tall and ſlender,
And ſhe's of the feminine gender.
Her voice as a flute is dulcis,
And ſoft when tacto her pulſe is.

sp.speaker: Engene.
sp.p: Well, Thomas.

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: I've been taking a mug of ale at the Griffiin, ſir; and a lady juſt come from London deſied me to give you that there letter.

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: Mrs. Cheſhire's hand, my old Calypſo of Tooley-ſtreet.

body.p: I wiſh I could ſay dear Eugene; but you know you are unworthy of ſuch an epithet, yet my good-nature obliges me to repeat the offer of my hand, which if you again reject, my attorney has inſtructions to ſue you for the money my goodneſs lent to your neceſſity.

closer.signed: Yours, if you pleaſe, MARGERY CHESHIRE.

postscript.p: P. S. I and my attorney will be with you immediately.

div.p: 'Sdeath! to be peſtered at ſuch a time with ſuch a fulſome, teazing old fool! her caſh that ſhe abſolutely forced upon me — What ſhall I do with her, a filly, ridiculous — Eh! egad! ſuppoſe I — Ha, ha, ha! — a thought ſtrikes me. It will involve her in a ridiculous ſituation. I'll procure her a more honourable reception than ſhe expects. Ha, ha, ha! Yes. Thomas ſhall ſet it a-going through the family. I'll tell it him as a ſecret, and he'll tell it over the houſe, and the more marvellous the eaſier ſwallowed.

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: O Sir, I've been looking for you The lady got here as ſoon as her letter. She's in the little parlour, and —

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: Huſh!

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: Sir! —

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: Thomas, I know you're honeſt.

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: That I am, ſir, as any ſervant in —

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: Thomas, can you — ſhut that door; can you keep a great ſecret?

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: Leave me alone for that, ſir.

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: O Thomas it's of the greateſt conſequence. If known, it may lay our country in ruin.

sp.speaker: Thomas
sp.p: I wont tell a word of it, ſir.

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: Not for your ſoul — Then, you muſt know — come this, way — that lady that gave you the letter, and that's now in the little parlour, is a Ruſſian Princeſs.

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: A Princeſs!

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: The Princeſs Ruſtifuſti. She fought a duel —

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: A Princeſs fight a duel!

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: With a great Count of the holy Roman empire. She was run through the ſwordarm; but the noble Count's wounds were ſaid to be mortal; ſo ſhe has fled to England for ſafety; and if ſhe's diſcovered, we muſt give her up: then, Thomas, ſhe'll be beheaded.

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: Poor noble ſoul!

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: Ay Thomas; ſuch a Princeſs! knows all languages, and Engliſh moſt correctly. Now, Thomas, if you mention this —

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: Me! not for —

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: Huſh! — not a word, eſpecially to a woman.

sp.speaker: Fringe.
sp.p: And why not to a woman pray?

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: Becauſe its a ſecret.

sp.speaker: Fringe.
sp.p: A ſecret! I muſt know it.

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: O, Mrs. Fringe, if you would not ſpeak of it —

sp.speaker: Fringe.
sp.p: Come, tell me

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: Then you muſt know — ſhut the door — this way — the great lady in the little parlour is a Ruſſian Princeſs.

sp.speaker: Fringe.
sp.p: A Princeſs!

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: The Princeſs Ruſky Fuſky. She killed two Counts of the holy Roman Emperor. She's here incog. And if ſhe's taken, her head will be chopped off. Not a word of that, Mrs. Fringe; for it's a raſcally thing to tell a thing once, you're intruſted with it.

sp.speaker: Fringe.
sp.p: So it is indeed, Thomas.

div.p: A Princeſs! I'll wait upon her. She may prefer me to be one of her maids of honour.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Did yon ſee Mr. Lingo? I want ſome cake and wine for this ſtrange gentlewoman here in the parlour.

sp.speaker: Fringe.
sp.p: Gentlewoman! well, I find ſome people know more of ſome people than ſome people. But when people intruſt people with people's ſecrets, people are not to tell them to all the people people meet.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Hey! the devil! what a crowd of people's here!

sp.speaker: Fringe.
sp.p: Eh! — no, we're alone. — ſhut the door — John, if you know — you won't tell any body?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Tell! did I tell of the bottle of burnt claret the other night, though I ſtole it from Mr. Lingo myſelf?

sp.speaker: Fringe.
sp.p: No, you have diſcretion, John, — John, that gentlewoman, as you call her, is — but it is the greateſt ſecret — ſhe is the great Ruſſian Princeſs Ruſky Fuſky!

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: The Princeſs Ruſky Fuſky!

sp.speaker: Fringe.
sp.p: She was ſet upon by five holy Roman Empires. The dear lady had nothing but her fan and her ſciſſars; and with theſe ſhe defended her honour, with her back againſt a tree, till ſhe laid the five holy Roman Empires all dead at her feet. If ſhe had ſtaid, ſhe would have had her head ſeveraled from her body; ſo ſhe called for her own maid, a faithful ſenſible body like me, one that never blabb'd, — ſhe packed up her portmanteau, croſſed the ſeas, and landed at Blackheath. If ſhe's taken — John don't tell, as her life's in danger.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Her life in danger! damme! if I'd tell for half a crown.

sp.speaker: Fringe.
sp.p: I believe you, John. I aſſure you I would n't have told you, only I know you can keep a ſecret as well as myſelf.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Can one get any thing by it though?

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: What cream is wanted for the morning, John?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Ha! my dainty dairy-maid!

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: Ha'done, do. I ſhould n't have thought of your impudence, John.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Zounds! I forgot the wine and cake for the Prin—gad! I'd like to have popt it out.—Ah, Cowſlip I could diſcover —

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: I don't care what you diſcover of me. Why did Mr. Lingo tell then?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: O, nothing.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Damn the old wig-block! he has the ear, and I fancy the lip too of every woman in the houſe.

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: Why, you're as tall, and your leg is not amiſs when you're behind the coach. But why don't you ſpeak the Latin tongue?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: I've more regard to decency, than to curſe and ſwear to innocent women, becauſe they don't underſtand me.

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: Does Mr. Lingo do ſo? certain and ſure he does come out with his nouns ſometimes.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Cowſlip, I'll tell you the ſecret if you'll affront him.

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: Ods-daiſy! but I'll huff him; will that do? I'll pull his wig. He's mighty proud of his wig. Now what's the ſecret pray?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: The ſecret is —
Coming! — don't tell. We 've a great Princeſs in the houſe.

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: A Princeſs! ods-daiſy! that's fine.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: The Ruſſian Princeſs Ruſky Fuſky.

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: The Princeſs Ruſky Fuſky!

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: She killed ſix knights of the holy Roman Emperor. She's in diſguiſe here. The conſtables are after her with a ſearch warrant, and ſhe'll be hanged if ſhe's taken. You have the ſecret now, and pray keep it, for my ſake.
Coming, coming!

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: Keep the ſecret! ay, that I will. — Lord! I'll go to the Princeſs Ruſky Fuſky, and then I muſt make haſte to the lawn, or all the ſports will be over, and Cudden my ſweetheart gone home, or mayhap dance with another girl. — John and Mr. Lingo — Ah! after all, I find Cudden has ſkimmed the cream of my affections.

lg.l: Lord! what care I for mam or dad?
why let them, ſcold and bellow;
For while I live I'll love my lad,
The youth he danc'd ſo well O!
So 〈◊〉 a lad was never ſeen,
The fair over night was come,
The lad was ſome what mellow;
Says he my dear, I'll ſee you home —
We trudg'd along the moon ſhone bright,
I'll kiss you here by this good night,
You rogue ſays I, you've ſ •• pp'd my breath,
Ye bells ring out my knell O!
Ag in I'd die ſo ſweet a death

div.p: O here comes Mr. Lingo, with his gibberiſh and his nonſenſe.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p:
O my ſweeteſt of Cowſlips, dulcis
puella! by my dexter and finiſter manus, your antic Caleb ſings Io Poeans to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: What do you ſay, you're in pain to ſee me, Mr. Lingo?

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: Gerunds, declenſions, verbs and adverbs;

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: I ſhould not ha' thought of your herbs.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: Aid me, Amor, the eight parts of ſpeech, ſingular, plural, nouns and pronouns!

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: Mr. Lingo, I does n't love curſing and ſwearing.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: Nominativo hanc, hunc et hoc.

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: Hock again! You're drunk with, hock for my part I believe. I deſire you'll ha' done, do.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: Ha' done, do! Hear this you azure woods, you purling plains, you verdant ſkies, you cryſtal ſwains, ye feathered fountains, tinkling groves, you cooing kids, ye capering doves! ſhe's in the imperative mood. O damnatus, obſtinatus mulier!

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: Do you ſay I'm a damn'd obſtinate mule? — How dare you call me names? I'll pull your wig for you, that's what I will.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: If my ſcholars was to ſee me now, they'd never let me whip 'em again in ſaecula ſeculorum.

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: For all your lorums and larning, I could larn you ſomewhat, if I had a mind, Mr. Schoolmaſter, but it's a great ſecret, or I could tell you the big lady in the little parlour is the Princeſs Ruſky Fuſky! how ſhe killed ſeven whole Roman Emperors; and how ſhe'll be hanged in chains if ſhe's catch'd; and I could have told you every word of it if I pleaſed; but you ſhan't know a ſyllabuh of it from me, that you ſhan't, Mr. Schoolmaſter.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p:
Multum in parvo. What a diſcreet
ſlut it is to know all this, and wouldn't tell even me, becauſe its a ſecret! The Princeſs Ruſky Fuſky in our houſe! this is indeed a ſecret, pro bono publico. This cowſlip is the very flower, the daffy-down-diliy of dairy-maids!

lg.l: With that I'd paſs my hours
To be ſure I would, tol, tol, &c.
And look'd ſo freſh and gay,
Says I, you're dreſs'd ſo neatly,
I loog'd to pull it dearly,
And ſtick it in my breaſt.

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: So, as I expected, my ſecret has gone through the family, and my cheeſemonger is a Ruſſian Princeſs.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: O Eugene, I hear ſir Felix's ſon is actually arrived.

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: Then my Laura, though bitter the ſeparation, I bid an eternal adieu to you and happineſs.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Do you leave the country, Eugene?

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: Can I ſtay to ſee my deareſt Laura — think what I would ſay.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Nay, Eugene, do tell me.

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: Sir Felix's ſon is arrived, and — Can I ſee you in the arms of another?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Ah, Eugene, if you go — do you, can you think your Laura will ſtay behind?

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: Generous Laura!— but ſir Felix has ſet his heart upon your union with his ſon. To his bounty my father and I owe our very exiſtence. And ſhall I, like a viper, turn and ſting my kind preſerver? no Laura. Though in the poſſeſſion of you, my love, I compriſe all hopes of happineſs; yet, in my mind, the height of human bliſs is dearly gained, when purchaſed by an action of diſhonour.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I aſk your pardon, ſir. — I ſee my error. — I ſhan't be ungrateful to ſir Felix — I'll give my hand where he commands, though my heart may burſt— Oh! Eugene, I did not think you'd uſe me thus.

lg.l: Ah! why take back the vows you gave,
Or wiſh to part with mine;
My heart is ſtill your willing ſlave,
A bird thoſe vows did firſt engage,
You've lull'd me in a dream of love,
And when the ſubſtance I would prove,

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: I cannot bear this, and fear love muſt triumph over gratitude. — And have you fortitude Laura, to face the world with me;

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Try me. And not even the elements ſhall part your faithful Laura from her beloved Engene.

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: Generous Laura!

lg.l: My Laura, will you truſt the ſeas,
For poor Eugene quit home and caſe.
As all our freight is love.
Our hark ſhall bravely ſtem the tide.
Till ſkies clear up, and ſtorms ſubſide,
As all our freight is love. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.p: Draws and diſcover Mrs. Cheſhire ſitting down Lingo, John and William ceremoniouſly waiting,

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: My patience is almoſt wearied out. Very ſtrange I can't ſee Eugene. — Oh dear! a glaſs of water, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: Madam! John don't know ſhe's a princeſs; and I can't do her proper homage before theſe Cyclops. John, yon may bo'h retire.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Mr. Lingo's not in the ſecret.
Mr. Liago, pray bow reſpectfully to her.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: Do you teach me that have teached hundreds? centum, docintum, you vile lictor! take your face out of the room, go. An't I the domeſtic god, the very Lary of the family? go.
Don't be afraid. Nobody knows yon but me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: Theſe Kentiſh ſervants are very civil.

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: Some of our Engliſh cream for your royal reverence!

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: My royal reverence!

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: Take the glaſs, pleaſe your catholio majeſty.

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: My catholic Majeſty!

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: Cowſlip, leave the preſence.

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: I have no more preſents than the bowl of cream.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: Cream! you ſhallow Pomona!

sp.speaker: Cowſlip.
sp.p: Well, till now I always thought your great Ruſſians wore whiſkers.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: Don't mind that girl, moſt learned Mufty. She's a mere Engliſh Druid, moſt divine bard.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: John, this honour is too great —

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Mr. Lingo, I was ordered —

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: John, I do not love a common Demoſthenus.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Sir, I —

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: Go out, unmannerly homo, go!
The moſt impudent canus in our domus.

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: This is wine. A glaſs of water, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: In vino veritas. You get not water in this houſe. Some cake for your faithful majeſty.

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: My majeſty! O, this is mere diverſion.— I ſent a letter juſt now from the Griffin to Mr. Eugene.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: You ſent it! Yes, he got a letter from the Griffin. — Take ſome cake. Vivitur, we live by eating and drinking, pleaſe your grace's holineſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: My grace's holineſs! pray harkee, Sir, does your maſter tolerate you to — but I — I'm cool.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: Cool! ſhe wants the Ruſſian ſtove. We have no ſuch in England, great Ottoman; but I'll immediately get you a chaſing-diſh of hot coals for your ſublime port.

sp.speaker: Fringe.
sp.p: Pleaſe your royal highneſs!

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: My royal highneſs!

sp.speaker: Fringe.
sp.p: I am my young lady's own woman, your royal highneſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: I am no royal highneſs, madam.

sp.speaker: Fringe.
sp.p: O! I know your royal highneſs very well; but I'd ſcorn to betray your royal highneſs, as it was in defence of your virtue you killed the Roman Emperors!

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: I kill the Roman Emperors!

sp.speaker: Fringe.
sp.p:
A Ruſſian princeſs! — Give me our o ••
• oy •• family after all!

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: All mad in this houſe, I believe.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: You will have the hot coals preſently. In the mean time throw this Ruſſian fur cloak over you. Mr. Compton wore it in your cold Eaſtern ports. You were wounded in the ſword-arm, great Ruſtifuſti.

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: Yes, this fellow's mad.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: Thoſe Roman Emperors that attacked you were mere Tarquins. Depend upon it, that chair is too low for your highneſs. Here is another. It is higher, and more fitter for your eminence.

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: Your highneſs is diſcovered.

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: Highneſs! all mad. I've got into Bedlam ſure.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: Whiſper a princeſs! why, Thomas, you fancy yourſelf Cardinal Wolſey in this houſe.

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: O! if you knew Mr. Lingo, —

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: What? Quid opus?

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: A ſecret. I met an attorney and a bailiff at the door.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: An attorney! — turn out.

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: It's my lawyer. Open the door.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: Let in an attorney! — are you mad, great potentate? — Oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: Open the door.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: The lawyer wilt betray you, commander of the faithful.

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: Open the door, I ſay!

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: Sit quiet, great Ruſtifuſti.

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: Am I to be ſhut up here with a madman? Open the door I inſiſt.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: Her ſerene highneſs is in a paſſion, She'll never be taken alive. Yes, ſhe'll kill the attorney. There is a caſe of piſtols. There is a broad fword. Heavens! how ſhe'll fight! here, now, defend yourſelf, brave Ruſtifuſti. —

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: Open the door I ſay.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: Yes, ſhe'll ſhoot the attorney. Stay, till I get up here. — Now prime, and fire away, brave Bellona.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Don't be alarmed, princeſs. Though your perſon's known here, you're ſafe by all the laws of hoſpitality.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: Stand out of the way, Domine Felix, till Ruſtifuſti ſhoots the attorney.

sp.speaker: Compton.
sp.p: Why this is Mrs. Cheſhire, our Southwark cheeſemonger.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: A cheſemonger! O Coelnm et terra! and have I ſtudied Syntax, Cordery, Juvenal, and Tiſtram Shandy, to ſerve wine on my knee to a mighty cheeſemonger! — But there is one thing I can never forgive in ſaecula ſaeculorum.

sp.speaker: Compton.
sp.p: What's that, Lingo?

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: Her not ſhooting the attorney.

sp.speaker: Chicane.
sp.p: So, ſo, the partly has abſconded.

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: Eugene!

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: My ſon run away!

sp.speaker: Chicane.
sp.p: With the young lady of the houſe I think.

sp.speaker: Compton.
sp.p: My daughter!

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Tol, lol, lol! — Ha, ha, ha! This is good. To avoid each other, gone off together. Ha, ha, ha! I am ſo happy.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: So, you two ran away to be married I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: With that intention, Sir, I confeſs.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Dear Sir Felix, the fault was mine; but Eugene's mind is replete with honour, and he has made me a proſelyte. O Sir! he has my affections. I here return to my obedience, with hopes a ſon of yours will never accept my hand, when my heart is poſſeſſed by another.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Refuſed a fine girl rather than violate the tie of honour and gratitude! — My Eugene! my ſon! take the bleſſing of a father; for I now with pride acknowledge you.

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: Sir! —

sp.speaker: Compton.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Eugene. Sir Felix claims your fillal duty.

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: I'm ſurpriſed!

sp.speaker: Sir. Felix.
sp.p: Yes, I love to ſurpriſe people.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Dear Sir!
your bleſſing and forgiveneſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Kneel there, Laura. His right is prior to mine.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Mr. Compton! —

sp.speaker: Compton.
sp.p: Yes, Laura, in me you behold an affectionate parent; but next to heaven you owe your thanks to that benevolent man.

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: Well, I'll be revenged if it coſt me half the cheeſe in my ſhop.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Stay, widow. Egad! I've ſurpriſed you. Suppoſe you ſurpriſe me in turn, and marry the attorney?

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: I own Mr. Chicane is an honeſt man, but —

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Honeſt! take him home — Bring an honeſt attorney over London Bridge with you, and you'll ſurpriſe all Tooley-ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.p: I hear of a wedding going to be, Domine Felix, therefore I will write a latin epitaph for the pair of bridegrooms, wherein I'll provoke the patronage of Cupid, Thomas a Becket, Sir Godfry Kneller, and Helley O'Gabalus.

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Let me have no more of your damn'd Godfreys and Gabaluſſus. Lay the cloth, and ſurpriſe us with a good wedding ſupper.

sp.speaker: Eugene.
sp.p: A wedding! Is it poſſible —

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.p: Yes, boy, poſſible, ay, and probable too. I've ſurpriſed you with the girl of your heart, and a good fortune. Is not this an Agreeable Surpriſe?

sp.speaker: Sir Felix.
sp.l: A kiſs, my girl; your hand, my boy;
There, now each anxious trouble ends;
Yet, be it ſtill my greateſt joy
With bleſſings to ſurpriſe my friends.
Each jovial heart he pleas'd this night —
What bleſſings in good-humour lies!
And proſpects yield more ſweet delight
By an agreeable ſurpriſe.

sp.speaker: Laura and Eugene.
sp.l: In pureſt robes of radiant light
Diana Ceres, Hymen, come.
You've bleſs'd the day, ſo crown this night,
Our birth-day, wedding, harveſt come.

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.l: Great Ruſtifuſti now no more
Nor Ruſſian princeſs here incog!
But widow Cheſhire as before,
And for a huſband ſtill agog!

sp.speaker: Crompton.
sp.l: Uncertain yet our poets fate,
Tis your award muſt fix his doom;
Applaud with joy he'll celebrate
Our birth-day, wedding, harveſt home.

sp.speaker: Lingo.
sp.l: For omnae bene he applies,
His DEAD ALIVE in critics paw,
Forgive th' AGREEABLE SURPRISE,
And ſpare him for his Son-in-Law.
Each jovial heart be pleas'd this night, &c.
